meta.description: Experts share the potential COVID-19 booster shot side effects you could experience if you qualify for a third dose of the vaccine, according to experts.
meta.keywords: side effects covid-19 booster, third dose

title: Qualify for a COVID-19 Booster Shot? 3 Potential Side Effects You Could Experience
cleaned_text:
COVID-19 booster shots have been authorized for a select group of people in the U.S. who received the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. And, if you’re one of them, you probably have some questions about what potential side effects you could experience after getting your third dose.

Now, a new study from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) breaks down exactly what you might go through (or not) after having a third dose of the COVID-19 vaccine. The study analyzed self-reported data from the CDC’s V-Safe vaccine safety reporting program of 22,191 people who received their third shots between August 12 and September 19, 2021.

Of the 22,191 who made reports to V-Safe, about 7,000 (32%) said they noticed any side effects. More than 6,200 (28%) reported they didn't feel well enough to do normal daily activities, usually the day after they were vaccinated.

The side effects—when people had them—were generally mild, and the researchers found that there were “no unexpected patterns of adverse reactions” after people received their third dose. Here’s what you need to know about COVID-19 booster shot side effects.

First, who qualifies for a COVID-19 booster shot?

The CDC says that people in the following groups who got the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine are now (or soon) able to get a COVID-19 booster shot:
• People who completed their initial vaccine series at least six months ago
• People who are 65 and older
• People who are at least 18 and have underlying medical conditions
• People who are at least 18 and work in high-risk settings
• People who are at least 18 and live in high-risk settings

What are the COVID-19 booster shot side effects?

Overall, the CDC study found that 79.4% and 74.1% had local (meaning, at the spot where they got the shot) or systemic (all over) reactions, respectively, after their third dose. Worth noting: 77.6% and 76.5% reported local or systemic reactions after the second dose—so these numbers are comparable.

The exact side effects people experienced, when they actually had side effects, included:

Some reported having general pain, with 7% describing it as severe, which the CDC defined as pain that makes "daily activities difficult or impossible." 



“The COVID vaccines have proven to be very safe and have been given to hundreds of millions of people,” says infectious disease expert Amesh A. Adalja, M.D., a senior scholar at the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security. “It is not surprising that a third dose does not have any concerning safety signal.”

“Overall, what they’ve shown is that, with the third dose, people shouldn’t expect anything much worse than they had with the second dose,” says John Sellick, D.O. an infectious disease expert and professor of medicine at the University at Buffalo/SUNY.

William Schaffner, M.D., an infectious disease specialist and professor at the Vanderbilt University School of Medicine, says he’s been telling patients that their side effects “will likely be very similar to what they experienced with the second dose of the vaccine.” But, he says, “[it's] not one for one. Some people may notice a little more side effects; Some will have less.”

How can you prepare for your COVID-19 booster shot?

If you didn’t feel physically amazing after your second COVID-19 dose, it’s understandable if you want to be mentally and physically prepared for your third. If this describes you, experts recommend planning to take it easy the day after your vaccine. “Some individuals might not want to schedule too much the next day until they see how they fare,” Dr. Adalja says.

Dr. Schaffner agrees. “We’ve been telling patients not to plan anything terribly strenuous for the next day, just in case they feel fatigued,” he says. With that, Dr. Schaffner says, it’s reasonable to “think about a day ahead” and plan on having the things you’d need for meals and fluids handy, just in case you’re not feeling well enough to leave your place the day after having your vaccine.

If you’re concerned about the possibility of missing work or school, Dr. Sellick recommends trying to schedule your booster on or just before a day you have off, just to be safe. Still, he says, “most people will feel just fine after having the vaccine.”
